channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: FBI probes Boston 'terror' blasts
item.description: The FBI launches a "potential terrorist inquiry" after two explosions at the Boston Marathon leave three people dead and at least 140 injured.

item.title: Police chief reassures over marathon
item.description: A senior Metropolitan Police officer reassures runners and spectators that the London Marathon will go ahead as planned, amid an ongoing security review.

item.title: Iran struck by major earthquake
item.description: Iran has been hit by a 7.8-magnitude earthquake, the most powerful for 40 years, with tremors felt across Pakistan, India and the Middle East.

item.title: Deaths mum made pledge to children
item.description: A pregnant woman whose children were found dead after she fell to her death from a car park pledged to keep them "safe" just hours earlier, it emerges.

item.title: Terror suspect's extradition opposed
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights rules a terrorism suspect should not be extradited from the UK to the US due to his mental health problems.

item.title: Thatcher's body at Westminster
item.description: The body of former Prime Minister Baroness Thatcher arrives at the Palace of Westminster, where a service will take place ahead of her funeral on Wednesday.

item.title: Harding named BBC News director
item.description: The former editor of The Times, James Harding, is named as the BBC's director of news, director general Tony Hall confirms.

item.title: Measles epidemic cases rise to 765
item.description: The number of cases in the Swansea measles epidemic reaches 765, as the UK health secretary urges parents in England to have their children vaccinated.

item.title: Home extensions red tape cut row
item.description: Government plans to double the maximum size of home extensions are a "recipe for community disaster", a Tory MP warns ahead of a Commons vote.

item.title: Circuses to face wild animal ban
item.description: Circuses in England will be prohibited from using wild animals in their shows from 1 December 2015, the government announces.

item.title: Facebook SOS rapist jailed for life
item.description: A serial sex offender finally brought to justice after a girl he raped pleaded for help on Facebook is jailed for life as a judge demands to know why he was free for so long.

item.title: Stuart Hall in court on sex charges
item.description: Broadcaster Stuart Hall appears at Preston Crown Court on charges relating to sexual offences.

item.title: Bercow not 'kitchen table blogger'
item.description: Sally Bercow, who is being sued for libel over a tweet she posted, was not "some kitchen table blogger", the High Court hears.

item.title: VIDEO: Tiny alleyway gets double yellow lines
item.description: An alleyway, which would not accommodate even the smallest car, has been painted with double yellow lines.

item.title: Troubled £535,000 Olympic art axed
item.description: Plans for a steam artwork on the Liverpool skyline, which has cost £535,000, are abandoned after 15 months of failed attempts to make it materialise.

item.title: Pietersen out of New Zealand series
item.description: Kevin Pietersen will miss England's Test series against New Zealand in May because of a knee injury sustained last month.

item.title: Ennis to appear in Anniversary Games
item.description: Great Britain's Jessica Ennis is to compete in the London 2012 Anniversary Games at the Olympic Stadium from 26 to 28 July.

item.title: Return like TV show - O'Sullivan
item.description: Ronnie O'Sullivan compares his comeback at the upcoming World Championship to a reality television programme

item.title: Rugby star wins new title as doctor
item.description: After a season helping Wales win the Six Nations and securing a new club in France, Jamie Roberts achieves his other career goal and qualifies as a doctor.

item.title: MPs call for Bahrain GP cancellation
item.description: A group of British MPs have called for the Bahrain Grand Prix to be be cancelled because of unrest in the Gulf state.

item.title: UK inflation steady at 2.8% in March
item.description: UK consumer price inflation stays at 2.8% in March for the second month in a row, the Office for National Statistics says.

item.title: House price inflation down, says ONS
item.description: House prices across the UK went up 1.9% in the 12 months to February, but the difference between London and other regions is increasing.

item.title: Building firms blacklist angers MPs
item.description: Building firms which set up a "systematic blacklist" of workers do not appear to be taking full responsibility for their actions, according to MPs.

item.title: Cable retracts One Direction 'attack'
item.description: Business Secretary Vince Cable retracts his comments over boy band One Direction's earnings.

item.title: '2m people unaware' of asthma risk
item.description: Two million people in the UK may be unaware they are at risk of a potentially fatal asthma attack, according to the charity Asthma UK.

item.title: Child heart surgery row doctor resigns
item.description: A senior doctor at the centre of the row over children's heart surgery has resigned.

item.title: Plans for lessons on Shakespeare
item.description: Children in UK primary schools are to learn about Shakespeare through drama, cookery and sport lessons, as the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust plans a special week for the Bard.

item.title: Maths plan risks 'too much too soon'
item.description: Plans to overhaul England's primary maths teaching would introduce "too much too soon" and could leave many pupils "by the wayside", a charity says.

item.title: Samsung probed over 'fake reviews'
item.description: Fair-trade officials in Taiwan are looking into reports that Samsung paid people to criticise rival HTC online.

item.title: Alibaba steps up battle with Android
item.description: Alibaba seeks to weaken Google's dominance of the Chinese smartphone market with subsidies and other support for its rival Amos operating system.

item.title: EU snubs plan to save carbon trading
item.description: The European Parliament has narrowly voted against a plan designed to breathe new life into the ailing carbon market.

item.title: Early hints of dark matter at US lab
item.description: Researchers at the American Physical Society meeting report three tentative clues in the long-running hunt for dark matter.

item.title: Mantel and Smith on prize shortlist
item.description: Hilary Mantel and Zadie Smith are among the six authors in contention for this year's Women's Prize For Fiction, formerly known as the Orange Prize.

item.title: North Korea book wins Pulitzer Prize
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize for fiction has been won by author Adam Johnson for his novel based in North Korea, The Orphan Master's Son.

item.title: Justin Bieber on Anne Frank: Five interpretations
item.description: Justin Bieber hopes Anne Frank would be a "belieber" - and he wrote it in the visitor's book of the Anne Frank museum. What does this say about him?

item.title: Blind drivers at the steering wheel
item.description: Innovations in automated driving have led to speculation that blind people may be able to take to the wheel. But do they want to drive?

item.title: Police to review marathon security
item.description: Security around the Greater Manchester Marathon is to be reviewed following explosions at the Boston Marathon in the US, police say.

item.title: Boy attacked for 'having red hair'
item.description: Three men are jailed for attacking a boy with red hair in an apparent act of revenge after another red-haired youth abused the sister of two of them.

item.title: Scots Thatcher debate postponed
item.description: A Scottish parliament debate on the legacy of Baroness Thatcher will now not take place on the same day as her funeral.

item.title: Scot tells of Boston blasts 'terror'
item.description: A Glasgow woman supporting a team of British runners at the Boston Marathon describes the chaotic scenes in the aftermath of the explosions.

item.title: NI runners' fear after Boston blasts
item.description: Runners from Northern Ireland who took part in the Boston Marathon express concern for fellow competitors after two explosions near the finish line.

item.title: Antrim A&E 'unsafe' say consultants
item.description: A group of senior consultants in Antrim Area Hospital describes the A&E department as "ineffective and unsafe".

item.title: Boston runner's 'unthinkable horror'
item.description: A runner from Wales speaks of the "unthinkable horror" after being caught up in two explosions near the finishing line of the Boston Marathon.

item.title: Assembly divide on Thatcher legacy
item.description: Welsh communities still feel bitterness from the miners' strike, says First Minister Carwyn Jones, but his Tory opposite number calls Baroness Thatcher a force for good.

item.title: Kenyan runner tells of Boston escape
item.description: Kenya's 2012 winner of the Boston Marathon Wesley Korir, who came 5th this year, tells the BBC of his fear after hearing of the deadly blasts.

item.title: Ghana gold mine collapse kills 16
item.description: At least 16 people have been killed when a disused gold mine collapsed in Ghana, local authorities say.

item.title: Musharraf barred from Pakistan polls
item.description: Pakistan's former military leader Pervez Musharraf is barred from standing in general elections in May.

item.title: China 'reveals military structure'
item.description: China reveals the structure of its military units, in what state-run media describe as a first.

item.title: Horse DNA in 5% of EU tested beef
item.description: Horse DNA is found in up to 5% of beef product tested across the EU, according to preliminary results published by the European Commission.

item.title: EU tightens up bank lending rules
item.description: MEPs approve far-reaching changes to EU banking rules, including curbs on bonuses and new capital buffers.

item.title: Venezuelans rally behind rivals
item.description: The main rivals in Venezuela's presidential election rally their supporters after the defeated candidate refuses to recognise the official result.

item.title: Spotify begins Latin America push
item.description: Music streaming service Spotify makes its first moves in Latin America and Asia, amid rumours Apple may be preparing a similar product.

item.title: UN presses world to act over Syria
item.description: The heads of five major UN agencies issue a rare joint appeal to the international community to do much more to end "cruelty and carnage" in Syria.

item.title: 'Tear gas fired' at Bahrain school
item.description: Police in Bahrain fire tear gas and clash with students in a raid on a secondary school in the capital, Manama, reports say.

item.title: US court hears gene patents case
item.description: The US Supreme Court hears arguments questioning whether the human genome can be claimed as intellectual property.

item.title: Obama to meet South Korean leader
item.description: US President Barack Obama will meet South Korean President Park Geun-hye in Washington in May amid high tension on the peninsula.

item.title: Day in pictures: 16 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 16 April

item.title: In pictures: Boston Marathon explosions
item.description: Two deadly bombs strike in Boston

item.title: In pictures: Royal Yacht Britannia at 60
item.description: A look back at the Royal Yacht Britannia

item.title: In pictures: N Korea celebrations
item.description: 101st anniversary of the birth of Kim Il-sung

item.title: In Pictures: Thatcher funeral rehearsal
item.description: Military rehearsal for Baroness Thatcher

item.title: Chris Bracey: Heaven and Hell
item.description: Light artist's first UK solo exhibition

item.title: Day in pictures: 15 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 15 April

item.title: In pictures: Mogadishu court attack
item.description: Attack on the main court buildings in Mogadishu

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are considering Lords amendments to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Bill.

item.title: What Liberace reveals about gay rights
item.description: How the flamboyant singer tried to hide the fact he was gay

item.title: Thatcher funeral: Can police stop protests?
item.description: Is it legal to demonstrate at a funeral?

item.title: Charlie does surf
item.description: How Apocalypse Now inspired surfers in the Philippines

item.title: Bahrain GP: Why is there unrest?
item.description: Why is there such opposition to staging the Grand Prix in Bahrain?

item.title: The bra designed to shock attackers
item.description: The most shocking bra you are ever likely to see

item.title: Butterfly beauty
item.description: A look at London museum's most precious specimens

item.title: Building the first 3D-printed house
item.description: 3D-printing pioneers race to make a canal house

item.title: Can streaming save music sales?
item.description: Can online streaming save music sales?

item.title: VIDEO: How do you build a Neolithic house?
item.description: Archaeologists at English Heritage are hoping to learn more about how our Neolithic ancestors lived by trying to build replica homes.

item.title: VIDEO: Westminster move for Thatcher's body
item.description: The body of former Prime Minister Baroness Thatcher is to be moved to a chapel in the Palace of Westminster later, ahead of Wednesday's funeral

item.title: VIDEO: Will handwriting survive the iPad?
item.description: Could interactive technology cause a drop in the number of individuals able to write by hand?

item.title: VIDEO: London Marathon 'will go ahead'
item.description: London Marathon chief executive Nick Bitel tells the BBC he fully expects the London Marathon to go ahead, despite the fatal explosions at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: VIDEO: Minute's silence for Hillsborough victims
item.description: Families of Liverpool fans who died at Hillsborough have gathered at Anfield for the annual memorial service.

item.title: VIDEO: Appeal to abandoned baby's mother
item.description: The police officer who took the baby abandoned in Edinburgh to hospital last week appeals to her mother to come forward.

item.title: VIDEO: Afghan farmers increase opium growth
item.description: Three times as much opium was produced in Helmand in Afghanistan last year as when British troops arrived there in 2006 - and this year's crop will be even higher, according to a new UN forecast.

item.title: VIDEO: EU horsemeat test results expected
item.description: Results of random tests for horse DNA in processed beef products are being published by the European Commission.

item.title: What's a fair nuclear price?
item.description: Why the government and EDF can't agree a new reactor deal

item.title: Is the NHS really untouchable?
item.description: The public may accept radical change, says Nick Triggle
